en_US.A free software to take back control of: A free software to take back control of your videos! With more than 100 000 hosted videos, viewed more than 6 millions times and 20 000 users, Tube is the decentralized free software alternative to videos platforms developed by Framasoft
en_US.Website developed by <a target=\"_blank\: Website developed by Framasoft and designed by Maiwann

This field must be filled in.
You must enter a valid email address.
en_US.In France, thanks to the %{ percent } ta: In France, thanks to the %{ percent } tax deduction, your donation of %{ amount } will cost you %{ defisc }.
en_US.At a time when no one knows what the fut: At a time when no one knows what the future holds, we deem it inappropriate to start a crowdfunding campaign and threaten not to do our best on Tube if we don't get the necessary funds.
en_US.We believe in the public utility of Tube: We believe in the public utility of Tube, so much so that we commit to working on it for six months to make this v3 happen, even if we must do it with our own funds (which we had already done for v2).
en_US.We still hope that by sharing this roadm: We still hope that by sharing this roadmap as widely as possible, some of you will support us in our approach with a donation that will allow us to fund this project.
en_US.<p>Today, when searching for videos on a:
Today, when searching for videos on a Tube instance, it is hard to find content that is not in the federation bubble of that instance.

We will create a server that indexes all videos and channels from all Tube instances that are listed on the public directory. The code for this indexing engine will be open source, so that anyone can host their own by setting their own eligibility rules.

Each Tube instance administrator will be able to choose to use one of these indexing engines for their instance's search bar.

In addition, announcements will allow instance administrators to display information to visitors.
en_US.<p>While each new version of Tube has br:
While each new version of Tube has brought new moderation features, there is still much to be done to facilitate moderation of content and accounts within the fediverse. That's why we want to dedicate a month to the development of new moderation tools.

The list of features we have to develop or improve is long: reports logs and monitoring, moderation history, comments moderation, moderation reports related to an account, feedback on steps taken (or not) following a report, fight against spam, sharing blocklists of instances, accounts or content...

This list is being built in collaboration with the community, and it is with these needs in mind that we will try to prioritize the moderation tools developed during this month.
en_US.<p>While it is easy to embed a Tube vide:
While it is easy to embed a Tube video on a website or social media, the same cannot be said for playlists. We want to rework the embed and display of playlists on third party websites.

We also want to allow two clips of the same video to be displayed in a playlist. Combined with the ability to extract a specific piece of video in a playlist, playlists will thus become very useful remixing tools, for example for educational purposes.

Plugins allow anyone to contribute to new Tube features by coding them into Tube, and offer them to instance administrators. We want to improve the plugin system to offer more interaction possibilities.

In order to put ourselves in their contributors' shoes, we are going to create a few plugins of our own, for example one to display information over a video to annotate it at a specific point in the viewing process.

Finally, we want to work on selecting a set of plugins to showcase them on joinpeertube.org.
en_US.<p>The biggest challenge of live streami:
The biggest challenge of live streaming on Tube is to get the live stream to be peer-to-peer. After extensive testing, we believe this is possible.

By using the HLS technology that has been built into the Tube video player since version 1.3, we believe we can create a live stream with one minute of lag between streamers and viewers.

We want to lay the technological foundation for this live stream feature, so this first version of Tube Live will be minimalist. There will be no stream captation tools, no built-in chat, no react emojis...

However, we want to make sure that once the live stream is over, the video will be processed and added to the creator's channel, with every requirement for proper federation checked.
en_US.Join me and support Tube, a free softwar: Join me and support Tube, a free software to take back control of your videos!
en_US.<strong>Framasoft</strong> (that's us!): Framasoft (that's us!) is a French non-for-profit organization created in 2004, dedicated to popular education on digital matters. Our small association (under 40 members, under 10 employees) is known to have made the "De-google-ify the Internet" project, offering 34 ethical and alternative online tools.
en_US.Our association creates digital tools (s: Our association creates digital tools (services, courses and resources, software) to equip the people who participate in a "contribution society". Amongst these, we lead the development of federated software Tube and Mobilizon (an upcoming alternative to Facebook events, pages and groups).
en_US.Recognised as being of general interest,: Recognised as being of general interest, over 95% of our association's budget comes from donations made by people who support and trust us.
en_US.Throughout this development period we wi: Throughout this development period we will be improving the user experience and interface of Tube to provide more clarity and power at every level of use.
en_US.« Independent designer, UX researcher wh: « Independent designer, UX researcher who seeks to acquire a thorough and deep understanding of uses and design user-friendly, ethical and inclusive tools. »

en_US.A few questions to discover Tube: A few questions to discover Tube
en_US.Tube is software that you install on a w: Tube is software that you install on a web server. It allows you to create a video hosting website, so create your "homemade YouTube".
en_US.The difference to YouTube is that it's n: The difference to YouTube is that it's not intended to create a huge platform centralizing videos from the whole world on a single server farm (which is horribly expensive).
en_US.On the contrary, Tube's concept is to cr: On the contrary, Tube's concept is to create a network of multiple small interconnected video hosting providers.
en_US.Tube is unique because (as far as we kno: Tube is unique because (as far as we know) it's the only video hosting web application which combines three advantages:
en_US.An open code under a free/libre license: An open code under a free/libre license
en_US.Tube is freely provided, no need to pay: Tube is freely provided, no need to pay to install it on your server;
en_US.We can look under the hood of Tube (its: We can look under the hood of Tube (its source code): it's auditable, transparent;
en_US.It can be enhanced by everyone's contrib: It can be enhanced by everyone's contributions.
en_US.A federation of interconnected hosting p: A federation of interconnected hosting providers
en_US.It decentralizes video storage and decis: It decentralizes video storage and decision-making power;
en_US.We can display videos and accounts of ot: We can display videos and accounts of other Tube websites;
en_US.It's based on <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\: It's based on ActivityPub to connect with tools like Mastodon for example.
en_US.It reduces server bandwidth overload if: It reduces server bandwidth overload if a video becomes viral;
en_US.We become an actor of the video broadcas: We become an actor of the video broadcasting;
en_US.It's based on <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\: It's based on WebRTC, a free and open-source project for web browsers.
en_US.Tube is developed by <a target=\"_blank\: Tube is developed by Framasoft, a French non-profit popular educational organization on digital issues.
en_US.It employs a developer, <a target=\"_bla: It employs a developer, Chocobozzz, who works since 2018 on Tube projects:
en_US.Development of new features and software: Development of new features and software maintenance;
en_US.Thoughts on the architecture, the design: Thoughts on the architecture, the design and the future of Tube;
en_US.New stable releases preparation and comm: New stable releases preparation and communication (blog posts, changelog, etc.);
en_US.<a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener nore: Official Tube website development and maintenance;
Tube plugins index development and maintenance;
Tube instances index development and maintenance;
Tube videos/channels search index development and maintenance;
Tube documentation website development and maintenance;
en_US.Tube support and discussions on bugtrack: Tube support and discussions on bugtrackers, forum, IRC or by email;
en_US.Pull requests/merge requests reviews, me: Pull requests/merge requests reviews, merges, and support of features added by external contributions (bug fixes, documentation, refactor, etc.);
en_US.Maintenance of several Tube instances (t: Maintenance of several Tube instances (tube.cpy.re, peertube2.cpy.re, etc.).
en_US.Moreover, Chocobozzz works on internal F: Moreover, Chocobozzz works on internal Framasoft's projects (Framapad, Framatalk, etc.). In other words, the management of Tube projects is operated by only one employee, who has other responsabilities in addition to his workload.
en_US.Other Framasoft's volunteers and salarie: Other Framasoft's volunteers and salaried members also contribute to the Tube project on various aspects (strategy, communication, development, community animation). Nevertheless, Tube is not developed by a startup with a team of 50 people, and a workflow full of hyper-formatted processes.
en_US.Framasoft will therefore takes the time: Framasoft will therefore takes the time to improve the software progressively, at its own pace and with its atypical methods which, so far, have proven to be rather effective.
en_US.Tube is a software created, developed an: Tube is a software created, developed and maintained by Framasoft, a French non-profit popular educational organization on digital issues. Framasoft has a French culture, respects French laws and is a political actor (« who participates in the life of the city-state ») of civil society.
en_US.Tube is part of several actions assemble: Tube is part of several actions assembled by Framasoft in the Contributopia roadmap. These actions aim to propose alternative digital tools to those coming from surveillance capitalism, so that people who do not recognize themselves in such a system can create spaces of freedom.
en_US.Consequently, Tube development and/or ma: Consequently, Tube development and/or management of websites associated with the Tube project (joinpeertube.org, instances.joinpeertube.org, search.joinpeertube.org, etc.) may not please everyone (in particular because of different ideas, ideologies of cultures).
en_US.We respect that, and remind that all sof: We respect that, and remind that all software of the Tube project is free software and can be installed with their own domain name.
en_US.We can answer with certainty: no!: We can answer with certainty: no!
en_US.The ambition remains to be <strong>a fre: The ambition remains to be a free and decentralized alternative: the goal of an alternative is not to replace, but to propose something else, with different values, in parallel to what already exists.
en_US.Yes, Framasoft holds the \"Tube\" tradem: Yes, Framasoft holds the "Tube" trademark in several countries for preventive purposes.
en_US.Framasoft affirms here its intention to: Framasoft affirms here its intention to not use intellectual property for predatory purposes or to constrain legitimate uses of the software. However, Framasoft reserves the right to use trademark law, especially in case of damage to the image of the Tube project, edited by Framasoft.
en_US.We recommend you to create your own digi: We recommend you to create your own digital identity, without using "Tube" for your project (software name, website domain...) to not confuse people about who is behind the website/project.
en_US.For more information, please refer to ou: For more information, please refer to our Trademark Code of Conduct.
en_US.Tube is just the name of the software. Y: Tube is just the name of the software. You can install it on your server, and choose the name you want. For example, Framasoft's Tube instance is named Framatube.

en_US.Tube is not a service, Tube is free soft: Tube is not a service, Tube is free software. This means that anyone can download and install Tube to host videos on a specific domain name (this is called "hosting a Tube instance/website"). Framasoft has no control over who downloads Tube, and who installs or uses it. Nor does Microsoft or Adobe have any control over who uses Word or Photoshop and for what purposes.
en_US.Framasoft only hosts and promotes one Tu: Framasoft only hosts and promotes one Tube instance: https://framatube.org
en_US.Also, Framasoft hosts and promotes only: Also, Framasoft hosts and promotes only one Tube search index: https://sepiasearch.org
en_US.This is not true. In September 2021, the: This is not true. In September 2021, the 900 instances listed on our public index host ~1% videos tagged as NSFW (i. e. the content is sensitive, which could be something else than pornography).
en_US.Administrators have full control of the: Administrators have full control of the content they want to display, and how they want to display it. In the default configuration, Tube hides NSFW videos.
en_US.See the dedicated section in the Tube do: See the dedicated section in the Tube documentation: https://tube.docs.dingshunyu.top/use-report
en_US.Your web browser sends a view to the ser: Your web browser sends a view to the server after 30 seconds of playback. If a video is less than 30 seconds in length, a view is sent after 75% of the video duration. After giving a view, that IP address cannot add another view in the next hour. Views are buffered, so don't panic if the view counter stays the same after you watched a video.

en_US.Being free doesn't mean being above the: Being free doesn't mean being above the law! Each Tube hosting provider can decide on its own general conditions of use, abiding by their local laws.
en_US.For example, in France, discriminatory c: For example, in France, discriminatory content is prohibited and may be reported to authorities. Tube allows users to report problematic videos, and administrator must then apply its moderation in accordance with its terms and conditions and the law.
en_US.There are none at the moment: Tube is a: There are none at the moment: Tube is a tool that we wanted neutral in terms of monetization.
en_US.For now, the solution proposed the <stro: For now, the solution proposed the support button under the video. This button displays a frame in which people who upload videos can display text, images, and links freely (link to Patreon, Tipeee, Paypal, Liberapay...).
en_US.We did not go any further, as we refuse: We did not go any further, as we refuse to tie our code to a particular content funding method, that might not fit all communities and deter others. It's the reason why we encourage developers to use the Tube plugin API to create their own monetization system.

en_US.The <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener: The installation guide is here (only in English).
en_US.If you need help, check the <a target=\": If you need help, check the help page.
en_US.Tube should run happily on a virtual mac: Tube should run happily on a virtual machine with 2 threads/vCPUs, at least 1 Gb of RAM and enough storage for videos. In terms of bandwidth, a lot will depend on which Tube instances you federate with and what your relation with them is (more about that below).
en_US.As a real life example, the Tube demonst: As a real life example, the Tube demonstration server https://tube.cpy.re runs on 2 vCores and 2GB of RAM. Average consumption is:
en_US.Network: ~200GB sent per month (https://: Network: ~200GB sent per month (https://framatube.org: ~1.5TB sent per month)
en_US.Except for video transcoding, a Tube ins: Except for video transcoding, a Tube instance is not CPU bound. Neither Nginx, Tube itself, PostgreSQL nor Redis require a lot of computing power. If it were only for those, one could easily get by with just one thread/vCPU.
en_US.You will hugely benefit from at least a: You will hugely benefit from at least a second thread though, because of transcoding. Transcoding is very cpu intensive. It serves two purposes on a Tube instance: it ensures all videos can be played optimally in the web interface, and it generates different resolutions for the same video. Tube support for offloading transcoding to other machines is being discussed, but not yet implemented.
en_US.1/2 GB of RAM should be plenty for a bas: 1/2 GB of RAM should be plenty for a basic Tube instance, which usually takes at most 150 MB in RAM. The only reason you might want more would be if you colocate your Redis or PostgreSQL services on a non-SSD system.
en_US.There are two important angles to storag: There are two important angles to storage: disk space usage and sustained read speed. To make a rough estimate of your disk space usage requirements, you want to know the answer to three questions:
en_US.What is the total size of the videos you: What is the total size of the videos you wish to stream?
en_US.Do you want to enable transcoding? If so: Do you want to enable transcoding? If so, do you want to provide multiple resolutions per video? Try this out with a few videos and you will get an idea of how much extra space is required per video and estimate a multiplication factor for future space allocation.
en_US.Which sharing mechanisms do you want to: Which sharing mechanisms do you want to enable? Just WebTorrent, or also HLS with p2p? If you want both, this will double your storage needs.
en_US.In terms of read speed, you want to make: In terms of read speed, you want to make sure that you can saturate your network uplink serving Tube videos. This should not be a problem with SSD disks, whereas traditional HDD should be accounted for: typical sustained read rates for a well tuned system with a 7200rpm hard disk should hover around 120 MB/s or 960 Mbit/s. The latter should be enough for a typical 1 Gbit/s network uplink.
en_US.A rough estimate of a traditional server: A rough estimate of a traditional server's video streaming network capacity is usually quite straightforward. You simply divide your server's available bandwidth by the average bandwidth per stream, and you have an upper bound.
en_US.Take a server for example with a 1 Gbit/: Take a server for example with a 1 Gbit/s uplink for example pushing out 1080p60 streams at 5 Mbit/s per stream. That means the absolute theoretical upper capacity bound is 200 simultaneous viewers if your server's disk i/o can keep up. Expect a bit less in practice.
en_US.But what if you need to serve more users: But what if you need to serve more users? That's where Tube's federation feature shines. If other Tube instances following yours, chances are they have decided to mirror part of your instance! The feature is called "server redundancy" and caches your most popular videos to help serve additional viewers. While viewers themselves contribute a little additional bandwidth while watching the video in their browsers (mostly during surges), mirroring servers have a much greater uplink and will help your instance with sustained higher concurrent streaming.
en_US.No it doesn't. You can't deploy multiple: No it doesn't. You can't deploy multiple Tube nodes behind a load balancer.
en_US.As far as we know, there are 3 limitatio: As far as we know, there are 3 limitations to handle a large amount of users in Tube:
en_US.Bandwidth: can be mitigated using <a tar: Bandwidth: can be mitigated using Tube redundancy system and cache servers that serve video static files in front of your Tube instance
en_US.Storage: can be mitigated using <a targe: Storage: can be mitigated using S3/Object storage
en_US.Video transcoding: we may implement <a t: Video transcoding: we may implement transcoding by remote workers in the future
en_US.If you notice performance problems or a: If you notice performance problems or a bottleneck at your scale, don't hesitate to create an issue to discuss it.
en_US.Framasoft tries to make around 4 major r: Framasoft tries to make around 4 major releases per year. Releasing a new Tube version takes a lot of our time, so we cannot change this release cycle.
en_US.There is no LTS version: only the latest: There is no LTS version: only the latest stable version of Tube is supported by Framasoft.
en_US.If you want to test the Tube develop bra: If you want to test the Tube develop branch, we provide nightly builds.
en_US.We <strong>try</strong> to keep compatib: We try to keep compatibility with the latest minor version (2.3.1 with 2.2 for example). Unfortunately we don't have enough resources to keep compatibility with other versions.
en_US.\"It's outrageous and unconscionable: yo: "It's outrageous and unconscionable: you're releasing a Tube version that doesn't contain the necessary tools to effectively manage videos claimed by rights holders, or to effectively manage the issue of online harassment in comments, or to effectively manage monetization through advertising, or to (insert here your request to Tube). It will never work! What do you intend to do about it?"
en_US.You're right. Tube is not the perfect to: You're right. Tube is not the perfect tool, far from it. And we never promised this software would include all the features corresponding to every use cases.
en_US.Remember that Tube has only <a href=\"#w: Remember that Tube has only one full time developer and a small handful of very involved volunteers. It is not a product developed by a start-up with a full time team and significant financial support.
en_US.So if you feel that Tube does not curren: So if you feel that Tube does not currently meet your needs, it's simple: don't use it right now. We remind you that we don't make money developing Tube, and if we obviously hope for its success, Framasoft does not depend on it to continue its activities.
en_US.<a href=\"#what-are-the-tube-features-fo: Yes it does! Since the first stable release of Tube in October 2018, every release added or improved moderation features:
en_US.<strong>Tube 1.1</strong> added bulk act: Tube 1.1 added bulk actions in the admin users table and instance/account muting;
en_US.<strong>Tube 1.2</strong> added the abil: Tube 1.2 added the ability to unfederate a video on blacklist; the notification system now shows reports, and new users;
en_US.<strong>Tube 1.3</strong> added the poss: Tube 1.3 added the possibility for admins to automatically quarantine new videos for new/untrusted users until a moderator reviews it. The instance's followers management was also reworked: UI is improved, follows can be denied;
en_US.<strong>Tube 1.4</strong> added a plugin: Tube 1.4 added a plugin system, and made sure plugins can for instance automatically blacklist videos or reject comments based on any rule (similar to Pleroma MRF);
en_US.<strong>Tube 2.0</strong> setup now asks: Tube 2.0 setup now asks the admin to answer questions regarding their moderation policy and dedication to it. Make a feature to automatically follow a public index of Tube instances part of core Tube, instead of leaving admins to script it themselves. This allows instance administrators to automatically follow instances of a "follow list" of their choice; a list which is self-hostable, so that communities can grow at their own pace;
en_US.<strong>Tube 2.1</strong> added an <em>i: Tube 2.1 added an internal privacy mode to videos (such videos won't be shared outside of the instance), and added quick access to moderation tools below the comments and hooks to create registration plugins (geoblocking or captchas for example); some third-party plugins already demonstrate this ability. This release also put emphasis on describing moderation features within the interface: warnings for features that might increase moderation work like autofollow, and descriptions to the action dropdowns.
en_US.<strong>Tube 2.2</strong> greatly improv: Tube 2.2 greatly improved video abuses management (search, abuses display, actions on the video or account etc), added moderation hooks and helpers in the plugins API and Framasoft developed an experimental Auto mute plugin based on public lists.
en_US.<strong>Tube 2.3</strong> improved the r: Tube 2.3 improved the report modal and added predefined reasons selection. This version made it possible to delete all the comments of an account and Framasoft developed an experimental Auto block videos plugin based on public lists.
en_US.<strong>Tube 2.4</strong> added ability: Tube 2.4 added ability to report accounts and comments, a messaging system between the local reporter of an abuse and moderators, and an abuse management view for users.
en_US.<strong>Tube 3.0</strong> added a dedica: Tube 3.0 added a dedicated view to manage comments of the instance (list, filter, remove in bulk etc).
en_US.Tube developers are committed to develop: Tube developers are committed to develop and improve moderation tools to make instances always easier to manage. We welcome you to take part in discussions to help ongoing efforts in that direction or suggest new ones!
en_US.View, share and update <a target=\"_blan: View, share and update Tube code

en_US.Develop plugins and themes using the <a: Develop plugins and themes using the getting started guide
en_US.Check the complete <a target=\"_blank\": Check the complete plugin/theme documentation
en_US.Get help on <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"n: Get help on Tube forum or ask new plugin/theme API in Tube issues
en_US.Tube uses ActivityPub because this feder: Tube uses ActivityPub because this federation protocol is recommended by the W3C and is also used by other projects like the social network Mastodon.
en_US.IPFS is a great technology, but it still: IPFS is a great technology, but it still seems too young for streaming large files. The Tube P2P system based on well established protocols like HTTP and WebRTC, and the redundancy system are more easy for us to use and to maintain.
en_US.DTube does not seem open source, because: DTube does not seem open source, because publishing only compiled code hinders freedom of modification.
en_US.Tube does not impose any remuneration mo: Tube does not impose any remuneration model. This is the choice we have made, and others (like DTube) have made other choices. So it's up to you to see what suits you.
en_US.We have a policy for contributions relat: We have a policy for contributions related to security. Please refer to our security policy and advisories.
en_US.Questions on Tube? Need help? You've com: Questions on Tube? Need help? You've come to the right place!
en_US.Tube, a free software to take back contr: Tube, a free software to take back control of your videos
en_US.Free software to take back control of yo: Free software to take back control of your videos
en_US.Search for Tube videos, channels and pla: Search for Tube videos, channels and playlists
en_US.Tube V4 with channel customization, play: Tube V4 with channel customization, playlists search, custom instance homepage and more video filters is out!
en_US.Tube, developed by Framasoft, is the fre: Tube, developed by Framasoft, is the free and decentralized alternative to video platforms, providing you over %{ videos } videos published by %{ users } users and viewed over %{ views } million times
en_US.<a href=\"https://framablog.org/2021/11/: Read the blog post
en_US.Tube aspires to be a <strong>decentraliz: Tube aspires to be a decentralized and free/libre alternative to video broadcasting services.
en_US.Our aim is not to replace them, but rath: Our aim is not to replace them, but rather to simultaneously offer something else, with different values.
en_US.A federation of interconnected hosting s: A federation of interconnected hosting services
en_US.Tube is not meant to become a huge platf: Tube is not meant to become a huge platform that would centralize videos from all around the world.
en_US.Rather, it is <strong>a network of inter: Rather, it is a network of inter-connected small videos hosters.
en_US.Anyone with a modicum of technical skill: Anyone with a modicum of technical skills can host a Tube server, aka an instance. Each instance hosts its users and their videos. In this way, every instance is created, moderated and maintained independently by various administrators.
en_US.You can still watch from your account vi: You can still watch from your account videos hosted by other instances though if the administrator of your instance had previously connected it with other instances.
en_US.This is just how a <strong>federation</s: This is just how a federation works!
en_US.And there's more! Tube uses <a target=\": And there's more! Tube uses ActivityPub, a federating protocol that allows you to interact with other software, provided they also use this protocol. For example, Tube and Mastodon -a Twitter alternative- are connected: you can follow a Tube user from Mastodon (the latest videos from the Tube account you follow will appear in your feed), and even comment on a Tube-hosted video directly from your Mastodon's account.
en_US.Mainstream online video broadcasting ser: Mainstream online video broadcasting services make money off of your data by analyzing your interactions so that they can then bombard your with targeted advertising.
en_US.Peertube is not subject to any corporate: Peertube is not subject to any corporate monopoly, does not rely on ads and does not track you.
en_US.Most importantly, <strong>you are a pers: Most importantly, you are a person to Tube, not a product in need of profiling so as to be stuck in video loops. For example, Tube doesn't use any biased recommendation algorithms to keep you online for hours on end.
en_US.All of this is made possible by Peertube: All of this is made possible by Peertube's free/libre license (GNU-AGPL). Its code is a digital "common", that belongs to everybody, instead of a secret formula that belongs to Google (in the case of Youtube) or to Vivendi/Bolloré (Dailymotion). This free/libre license guarantees our fundamental freedoms as users and allows many contributors to offer evolutions and new features.
en_US.With Tube, choose <strong>your hosting c: With Tube, choose your hosting company and the rules you believe in.
en_US.YouTube has clearly gone astray: its hos: YouTube has clearly gone astray: its hoster, Google-Alphabet, can enforce its ContentID system (the infamous "Robocopyright") or its videos recommendation system, all of which appear to be as obscure as unfair.
en_US.Direct contact with a human-scale hoster: Direct contact with a human-scale hoster allows for two things: you no longer are the client of a huge tech company, and you can nurture a special relationship with your hoster, who distributes your data.
en_US.With Tube, you get to choose your hostin: With Tube, you get to choose your hosting provider according to their terms of use, such as their disk space limit per user, their moderation policy, who they chose to federate with... You are not speaking with a huge tech company, so you can talk it out in case of any issue, need, desire...
en_US.The Tube software can, whenever necessar: The Tube software can, whenever necessary, use a peer-to-peer protocol (P2P) to broadcast viral videos, lowering the load of their hosts.
en_US.In this way, when you watch a video, you: In this way, when you watch a video, your computer contributes to its broadcast. If a lot of people are watching the same video at the same time, their browser automatically send smalls pieces of the video to the other viewers. The server resources are not over-exploited: the stream is split, the network optimized.
en_US.It might not look like it, but thanks to: It might not look like it, but thanks to peer-to-peer broadcasting, popular video makers and their videos are no longer forced to be hosted by big companies, whose infrastructure can stand thousands of views at the same time... or to pay for a robust but extremely expensive independent video host.
en_US.Enjoy every feature: history, subscripti: Enjoy every feature: history, subscriptions, playlists, notifications...
en_US.Peertube is a <strong>free/libre softwar: Peertube is a free/libre software funded by a French non-profit organization: Framasoft
en_US.Our organization started in 2004, and no: Our organization started in 2004, and now devotes itself to popular education about digital technology issues. We are a small structure of less than 40 members and under 10 employees, well-known for the De-google-ify Internet project, when we offered 34 ethical and alternative online tools. As a public interest organization, over 90% of our funding comes from donations (tax deductible for French taxpayers).
en_US.Thanks to our <a href=\"/hall-of-fame\": Thanks to our crowdfunding (from March to July 2018), Framasoft were able to employ Tube's main developer. After a beta release in March 2018, release 1 came out in November 2018. Since then, several intermediary releases have brought many features along. Several collectives have already created Tube hosts, laying the foundation for the federation.
en_US.The more people use, support, and contri: The more people use, support, and contribute to Tube, the quicker it will become a concrete alternative to platforms like YouTube.
en_US.If you would like to interact with video: If you would like to interact with videos (like, comment, download...), subscribe to channels, create playlists or play videos, then all you have to do is create an account on the Tube instance of your choice.
en_US.1. Find the instance that suits you best: 1. Find the instance that suits you best
en_US.By <strong>filtering according to your p: By filtering according to your profile (video maker or viewer), topics that you are looking for or languages you speak, find an instance whose rules match your needs!
en_US.2. Create your account and enjoy Tube: 2. Create your account and enjoy Tube
en_US.A username, an email, a password and you: A username, an email, a password and you can already enjoy all the features of Tube!
en_US.Thanks to our crowdfunfing contributors,: Thanks to our crowdfunfing contributors, Tube V3 with live streaming support, global search, playlists embed and more moderation tools is out!
en_US.<a href=\"https://framablog.org/2021/01/: Read the blog post for more information
en_US.Let's pave the way to Tube live streamin: Let's pave the way to Tube live streaming in v3!
en_US.Donate, share: we will need all the help: Donate, share: we will need all the help we can get to complete this roadmap.
en_US.From June to November 2020, Framasoft wi: From June to November 2020, Framasoft will develop new features and improvements for Tube. We have broken down this roadmap into 4 main steps, each with its own schedule and cost, leading to the addition of peer-to-peer powered live streaming to Tube v3.
en_US.These developments are funded by donatio: These developments are funded by donations made to our small nonprofit organization: Framasoft. We will be raising funds progressively over the next six months of development, so that you can help us in our efforts.
en_US.\"Another\" world cannot be built using: "Another" world cannot be built using surveillance capitalism's tools.
en_US.Making it easier to access content, shar: Making it easier to access content, sharing power and responsibilities, opening up to contributions, generalizing live broadcasting thanks to peer-to-peer... Tube’s v3 aims to consolidate it as an alternative to Google-Youtube and Facebook-Live that is more and more convivial.
en_US.The money donated via this form will be: The money donated via this form will be exclusively dedicated to the Tube project.
en_US.Thank you very much for your donation to: Thank you very much for your donation to the Tube project!
en_US.Thanks to you, Framasoft’s teams will be: Thanks to you, Framasoft’s teams will be able to continue and expand the work already started on this software.
en_US.The success of this fundraising depends: The success of this fundraising depends only on you: we need you to raise awareness about this roadmap, so we can share our enthousiasm about Peertube's v3.
en_US.Feel free <strong>to share your gesture<: Feel free to share your gesture on your favourite social networks and to talk about Tube around you!
